title: Presumed Guilty
authors: Andrew Schneider and Mary Pat Flaherty
historical_context: This article discusses the implications of civil asset forfeiture laws in the United States, particularly in the context of the War on Drugs during the late 20th century.
target_audience: Civil rights advocates, legal professionals, law enforcement officials, and individuals interested in drug policy and civil liberties.
short_summary: The article reveals how civil asset forfeiture laws, originally intended to target drug dealers, have led to the wrongful seizure of property from innocent individuals, often based on racial profiling and without any criminal charges.
summary: In 'Presumed Guilty,' Schneider and Flaherty expose the troubling realities of civil asset forfeiture laws that have emerged in the United States, particularly since the 1984 amendments aimed at combating drug trafficking. Through extensive research, the authors document numerous cases where innocent citizens, often from marginalized communities, have had their property seized without any evidence of wrongdoing. The article highlights the disturbing trend where law enforcement agencies profit from these seizures, leading to a system where individuals are presumed guilty until proven innocent, undermining the foundational principle of justice in America. The authors present compelling narratives of victims like Willie Jones and the Lopes family, whose lives were irrevocably altered by these laws, illustrating the collateral damage inflicted by a legal framework designed to combat drug crime but instead targeting the innocent.
